objects.description: [APT17](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0025) posted in forum threads and created profile pages in Microsoft TechNet.

external_references.description: FireEye Labs/FireEye Threat Intelligence. (2015, May 14). Hiding in Plain Sight: FireEye and Microsoft Expose Obfuscation Tactic. Retrieved January 22, 2016.

objects.name: APT17
objects.description: [APT17](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0025) is a China-based threat group that has conducted network intrusions against U.S. government entities, the defense industry, law firms, information technology companies, mining companies, and non-government organizations. (Citation: FireEye APT17)

external_references.description: FireEye Labs/FireEye Threat Intelligence. (2015, May 14). Hiding in Plain Sight: FireEye and Microsoft Expose Obfuscation Tactic. Retrieved January 22, 2016.

objects.name: Build social network persona
objects.description: For attacks incorporating social engineering the utilization of an on-line persona is important. These personas may be fictitious or impersonate real people. The persona may exist on a single site or across multiple sites ([Facebook](https://www.facebook.com), [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com), [Twitter](https://twitter.com), [Google+](https://plus.google.com), etc.). (Citation: NEWSCASTER2014) (Citation: BlackHatRobinSage) (Citation: RobinSageInterview)

external_references.description: Mike Lennon. (2014, May 29). Iranian Hackers Targeted US Officials in Elaborate Social Media Attack Operation. Retrieved March 1, 2017.
Thomas Ryan. (2010). “Getting In Bed with Robin Sage.”. Retrieved March 6, 2017.
Joan Goodchild. (2010, July 8). The Robin Sage experiment: Fake profile fools security pros. Retrieved March 6, 2017.

objects.x_mitre_detectable_by_common_defenses_ex: Unless there is some threat intelligence reporting, these users are hard to differentiate.
objects.x_mitre_difficulty_for_adversary_explana: Performing activities like typical users, but with specific intent in mind.
